mission_summary: The primary objective of this 60-sol mission is to conduct a multi-faceted exploration of Mars, focusing on identifying geological evidence of past water activity, collecting samples for exobiological analysis, and deploying environmental sensors for atmospheric monitoring. The mission will employ a rover, drone, and satellite, leveraging a balanced strategy that prioritizes scientific discovery while strictly adhering to rigorous safety protocols and dynamic resource management. Proactive hazard avoidance, efficient data handling, and adaptive scheduling are paramount to ensure mission success within the strict operational constraints.

scientific_priorities.name: Survey Ancient Riverbeds and Lakebeds
scientific_priorities.target_location: Eridania Basin Outflow Channels (e.g., node_X501, node_X502)
scientific_priorities.justification: This objective is crucial for understanding Mars' past habitability and climate evolution by directly investigating geological features formed by long-term liquid water. Rover will use panoramic cameras, spectrometers, and ground-penetrating radar.

scientific_priorities.name: Core Sample Collection from Sedimentary Layers
scientific_priorities.target_location: Jezero Crater Delta Deposits (e.g., node_Y601, node_Y602)
scientific_priorities.justification: Sedimentary layers are prime locations for preserving biosignatures. Collecting and analyzing samples from these areas is a direct step in the search for ancient Martian life. Requires rover-mounted drill and sample handling system.

scientific_priorities.name: Long-term Atmospheric Monitoring Network
scientific_priorities.target_location: Multiple strategic locations including Landing Zone (node_S001), Elevated Ridge (node_A008), and Protected Depression (node_U207)
scientific_priorities.justification: Continuous monitoring of key atmospheric parameters (temperature, pressure, wind, dust levels) provides essential context for surface operations, aids hazard prediction, and contributes valuable data for Mars climate modeling. Sensors deployed by both rover and drone.

hazard_zones.time_window: Variable, potential for multiple days (e.g., Sol 10-13, Sol 35-38), can occur with sudden onset.
hazard_zones.recommendation: All outdoor rover/drone activities must be suspended immediately upon dust storm detection. Orient solar panels for maximum protection against abrasion and dust accumulation. Enter low-power standby mode, conserve energy, and await clear atmospheric conditions. Prioritize mission-critical communications during designated windows if atmospheric conditions allow. Do not attempt to traverse through active dust storms.

Maintain a minimum safe standoff distance of 50 meters from all identified steep cliff edges. Prioritize high-resolution imaging and altimeter data for any routes planned near these zones. Absolutely no traversal or direct approach to the cliff edge. Utilize drones for remote reconnaissance of areas bordering steep cliffs to identify safer passage or confirm no-go zones.

Approach identified unstable terrain with extreme caution. Reduce speed to less than 0.05 m/s. Actively monitor wheel slip, pitch, and roll. Prioritize alternative routes around severely unstable areas (e.g., deep regolith, loose rock fields). Conduct regular visual inspections of wheels and suspension components after traversing such zones. If traversal is necessary, use short, controlled movements and evaluate progress frequently.

critical_constraints: Rover operations are strictly dependent on solar power; extended activities require sufficient sunlight and adherence to the daily energy budget.
Communication with mission control is limited to two 2-hour windows per sol (08:00-10:00 and 18:00-20:00 Local Mars Time) via MRO.
All outdoor rover and drone activities must be suspended immediately upon confirmed detection of an imminent or active dust storm.
A minimum safe standoff distance of 50 meters must be maintained from all identified steep cliff edges (e.g., HZ_SC_001 affected nodes). Absolutely no traversal or direct approach to a cliff edge.
When approaching identified unstable terrain (e.g., HZ_UT_001 affected nodes), speed must be reduced to less than 0.05 m/s, and alternative routes around severely unstable areas are prioritized.
Dynamic Energy Management (DEM) system must be implemented to dynamically reallocate energy based on real-time factors and prioritize critical system functions and buffer reserves.
Proactive Drone Reconnaissance must be maximized for advance scouting of rover paths, especially near hazards, to identify safe routes and conserve rover resources.

Tiered Data Prioritization (e.g., Critical Telemetry > Emergency Data > Sample Analysis Data > High-Res Imagery) and Aggressive Compression must be enforced to optimize bandwidth within communication windows.

Communication Window Utilization must be optimized with a flexible, prioritized schedule; initial portions of windows dedicated to critical uplinks/downlinks, with rapid override capabilities for emergencies.
Predictive Hazard Modeling for dust storms must be integrated with real-time hazard mapping into an adaptive mission planning system to enable proactive adjustments.
Onboard data processing capabilities must be utilized to maximize pre-processing, analysis, and summarization of scientific data before transmission.
Robust Contingency Data Buffering must be established on all assets to manage data accumulation during communication outages.

contingency_plans.dust_storm_emergency: Upon confirmed detection, immediately cease all rover/drone movement. Engage braking. Stow solar arrays (if possible). Power down non-essential systems, enter low-power survival mode. Monitor power. Maintain communication capability if conditions permit. Mission objectives are secondary to system survival. Do not attempt to traverse through.
contingency_plans.steep_cliff_emergency: If inadvertently approached, immediately halt all movement. Engage braking/stabilization. Conduct high-resolution remote survey. Attempt slow, controlled reversal along last known safe path if precarious. No lateral/forward movement or turns. Report to mission control for re-routing.
contingency_plans.unstable_terrain_emergency: If encountered (e.g., wheel slip, sinking), immediately halt forward movement. Engage differential lock. Attempt gentle, controlled corrective maneuvers for extraction. Avoid aggressive movements. If unable to self-extract, power down non-essentials and await remote assistance.
contingency_plans.communication_outage: Activate robust onboard data buffering across all assets. Prioritize critical telemetry and essential commands for the next available window. Utilize onboard processing to summarize and compress data. Implement staggered downlink when conditions improve to prevent overwhelming bandwidth.
contingency_plans.energy_shortfall: Initiate Dynamic Energy Management to reallocate power, prioritizing life-support and core systems. Reduce non-essential operations and science activities. Enter extended low-power standby mode until solar input recovers. Re-evaluate mission timeline and objectives with mission control.
